commentBody:
Entertaining, and it solved smoothly, but I was sort of disappointed that it didn't resist me any more. I want my Saturday puzzles to have more bite to them. But maybe I was just lucky with the particular clues and answers in this one--or some good guesses.

I wouldn't spell TEENTSY with the extra T, but I can hear people pronouncing it that way--maybe it's a more regional thing?

I hope Christina and Jacob will collaborate on future puzzles!

Another one of the easier Saturdays.

Was I in bad mood, 
or was nothing terribly funny in this puzzle?

CLEAR SIGN 
I DONT CARE
Smooth sailing for a Saturday, but some clever and fun clues. Loved ‚ÄúWrigley field?‚Äù In the vein, I was looking for ‚Äúmitt‚Äù for ‚ÄúBrewer‚Äôs need‚Äù since I grew up in Milwaukee.

A great puzzle for a Saturday. I liked the clues. Top banana made me laugh, never heard of it, but I will be using it in the future.

Teentsy is not spelled with a t, but I'll allow it.

This was an odd one for me.  There were a lot of clues with twists, but miraculously none of them seemed to hang me up for long and the puzzle was over before I knew it.  My biggest hang up was suet for alternative to birdseed rather than RICE.  I liked the clues for SANDBOXES, IRONMINES, COINTOSS, and CHEWINGGUM among others.  I also liked the Will Rogers quote, which I had not heard before.

Back from Hawaii, because with everything being so calm in the world, it felt like a good time to visit paradise.  And it truly was. But good to be home!

Caitlin summed up my feelings about this puzzle:  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs heavy on wit, light on obscurity and entertaining to solve, solo or with your own pal.‚Äù  My solving pal was my dog, who I missed slightly more than I enjoyed basking in paradise.
I done did this puzz

Disagree with TEENTSY spelling. 

Raiders org slowed me down a lot, I was sure it was NFL.

My ongoing series of interesting wrong answers:

Caitlin Clark is a SHENOM. I guess I made that up, but it seemed apt.

A Good Samaritan is an ALIEN. As in, a person from another land who was able to treat a stranger with humanity. Most of my wrong answers make me laugh, but this one made me sigh.
Felt like a slog but faster than average.  Nothing really stood out for me but I too balked at ‚Äò teentsy‚Äô no matter how many times it‚Äôs appeared before‚Ä¶

Yep, it‚Äôs 3am and my valiant effort to tiptoe to the kitchen noiselessly for a glass of water flopped. As I reached the refrigerator, I heard a happy ‚ÄúRrrr!‚Äù and turned around to see the same eager, silver dollar-sized eyes over the same tuxedo as in the column photo. Se√±or Gato is ready for action. Freya help me. 

A lovely puzzle with very little glue (only four 3-letter entries in the whole grid), but‚Ä¶ but‚Ä¶ I would have loved more resistance. Measured in wee-hour meow-MEOWWWs, it lasted only a couple dozen.

Happy Saturday, fellow crossword warriors.
Nice puzzle.  Only gripe is TEENTSY.  Never saw it spelled that way.

I couldn't find "teentsy" in any online dictionary besides vocabulary.com. And even then they provided no examples. I don't know their reputation...

Is this so archaic it's not included in OED or MW dictionaries anymore? Or so new it hasn't hit them?

Loved it. Not my best time (right around 20 minutes for me) but I was kind of sad when it was over.

See, you can still make a proper Saturday Crossword without a ton of obscure proper names. Cough cough.

I had rookie for Caitlin Clark.  Thought I was being clever!  She is a PHENOM, though!

Enjoyed the puzzle!

Thanks!

"I don't know my unit circle."
"That's a clear sine you should study."

("Do you know trig?"
"Of course! I have a degree in radians.")

Like some of your other commenters I like a little more meat to a Saturday puzzle.  I'm sure I am better at them than I once was, and I know there are people here can polish off a Saturday in 8 minutes, but this was more like a Wednesday.  

Having said that, there are some great clues.  Wrigley field?  is one; and like Caitlin I wondered if Ms Clark is an Ohioan or a Utahan or a Mormon before the crosses gave it away.

Yes, humor and congeniality indeed, several possibles for the Lewis List. I'm on the fence about "The" Mona Lisa; it's commonly referred to as simply Mona Lisa, from the Italian "Monna Lisa" (M'lady Lisa), and while Italians still refer to it as "La Gioconda" which would translate more to Mrs. Gioconda -- Lisa was the wife of Francesco del Giocondo. On the other hand, it's such a bigtime painting, calling it "The" Mona Lisa conveys a sort of singularity to it, like "The Ritz" and "The Empire State Building." How do we know that it is a painting of Lisa del Giocondo and not Isabella of Aragon, or, as Freud speculated, only nominally of a Florentine noblewoman and that the enigmatic smile is a pentimento of Da Vinci's own mother, granting benign approval to Da Vinci's various projects as her eyes follow him around the room? Because a scholar discovered in a German library in 2005 in a 1477 edition of Cicero a marginal note from 1503 written by Agostino Vespucci, one of Da Vinci's acquaintances and admirers, who is reminded of Da Vinci by a passage in Cicero and ends his marginal comment by remarking that Da Vinci was working at the time on a portrait of Lisa del Giocondo. The smoking gun! It's astonishing that a rather boring painting like The Mona Lisa is considered the Top Banana out there. I much prefer Carol Lew's portrait of Tuxedo Cat, and it costs a lot less, too: https://oldworldpetportraits.com/product/tuxedo-cat-oil-painting-template-maurice-framed-or-unframed/

Took just a TEENTSY bit longer than Friday‚Äôs, both of which were less than half Thursday‚Äôs total‚Äî not really close to a PB, but I don‚Äôt recall many Saturday‚Äôs being quicker solves. And yet, it was crunchy enough that there was a moment when I wondered if I would be able to complete it. These are my favorite types of puzzle: I almost always persevere, and find the seemingly impossible quite solvable. If only I could transfer that unflappable determination to other areas of my life‚Ä¶ sigh. 

This one had some nice cluing, and very little crosswordese. No huge ahas, but some nods of appreciation. And even though TEENTSY did elicit a bit of raised eyebrow, the spelling does match my pronunciation, so I won‚Äôt complain!

You know, everyone talks about how beautiful the Mona Lisa is, but to be honest, I think I find almost everybody painted by Botticelli to be more comely.

No offense if you were the model for the Mona Lisa.  It may just be me.

Thank you, Christina and Jacob, for a superb Saturday solve! I found the puzzle to be vibrant and smooth rolled into one, and really enjoyed the romp. To Caitlin, I say: I can't believe my mind went nowhere near pinball nor real estate when I saw [It requires a flipper]; only snorkeling. That's three misdirects for just one clue! And I truly thought at first that the one always seen in a fancy fur coat would be some kind of diva. (Then again, I guess cats could be divas sometimes...) As for my musical accompaniment to this puzzle, the first one is the obvious Billy Joel "SHE'S Got a Way" https://youtu.be/i1waaD72R3E?si=WDL5NRWwZ9KNzsFa, followed by a nod to 1A, a heavy metal band that's no, not Iron Maiden, but rather Metallica with a beautiful ballad, "Nothing Else Matters" https://youtu.be/tAGnKpE4NCI?si=f6_C_7bsx9qVgehp Here's wishing everyone a wonderful weekend!

I guess I have to agree with several people who said it was easy for a Saturday, since I did actually manage to complete it, which only happens maybe half the time for me at best. It was pretty much in my own personal sweet spot for challenge vs doability. I was very happy to see the gold star when I typed my last letter in. Of course it was the extra T in TEENTSY, which I think is a small sacrifice to make for the greater good of actually having a puzzle to solve.

Seems I'm once again the minority curmudgeon, but besides the almost universal condemnation of TEENTSY:

"... light on obscurity"?!
DINKINS, TANTO, TUXEDOCAT, TRINIDAD, ALAN. These are commonly and widely known (i.e. not obscure) factoids, where?

Also, the definition of ORBED to mean encircled is noted (Merriam-Webster) as "Archaic", which I believe is generally believed to make it obscure.

I'll make one small concession that maybe I'm the only one who's never heard of the polital group ACTUP. But that's offset by the double-bad offense of constructors inventing, and editors accepting, a new spelling for "teensy"! 
Can we expect "itsty-bitsty" to appear soon?

I had the strangest experience with this one that makes me question my grip on reality.

I could have sworn the first three(!) times I looked at 21A, I was absolutely sure it was mayor of *Detroit*.

When the crosses finally pointed to DINKINS, I thought, "but that's for New York City".  And I looked at the clue, and sure enough it had changed to New York City.

I wish I had been born smart instead of so devastatingly handsome.
I would like to thank A Tribe Called Quest, and specifically Phife, for me knowing, or at least being able to guess, the answer to 21 across.

Spoiler for the mini crossword below...


I did not get TEENTSY as well. I had it spelled as teensie.  

Also, I had BIGKAHUNA, at first, having just come over from the mini. Is it possible that puzzle was there on the same day for an intentional misdirect? Lol

I had to look up a couple of things, but over all, nice puzzle.

SACRE bleu! What a lot of tiny complaints there are about TEENTSY‚Äîbut I DON't CARE. Most people seem to have the same take on the puzzle that I did: Entertaining fills, fun to solve, and full of drama (always welcome).

Thanks, Christina and Jacob, looking forward to more.
Yes Caitlin Clark is as famous here as anywhere! I know people who have gone to games at crypto arena just to see her play
‚ÄúTeentsty‚Äù may be one of the most inelegantly spelled words I‚Äôve ever seen‚Äîand it has no place in this otherwise reasonable puzzle.
I'm surprised so many people thought it was so easy.

Phew! I almost broke my streak by accident.  Being in the U.S. Pacific time zone, three hours behind New York, I usually solve the night before the puzzle‚Äôs actual date. However, on Friday night, I realized that I had not solved Friday‚Äôs puzzle so I quickly dashed it out and finished at 8:45 PM Pacific time/11:45 PM New York time.  So I was a mere 15 minutes away from losing my streak which is now over seven years.   

Now, I suppose I should put streak in quotes because I allow myself to do a little bit of research, such as looking at a map or the Wikipedia page for a movie, occasionally. I know that some feel that this doesn‚Äôt ‚Äúcount‚Äù. But it‚Äôs my streak and I‚Äôm always happy to complete the puzzle.  I learn more when I let myself do research but I like the challenge of avoiding it.  When I started solving, no amount of googling would have allowed me to finish a Friday or Saturday puzzle.  

This experience is a reminder to me not to borrow trouble.  The reason I forgot to do the Friday puzzle earlier is that I got anxious about the doctor‚Äôs appointment I had today which, thankfully, turned out to be no cause for concern.  Once again, I proved Mark Twain correct when he said, ‚ÄúI've had a lot of worries in my life, most of which never happened.‚Äù  How many times must I re-learn this? 

The puzzles continue to delight me. Oh, and I solved Saturday‚Äôs puzzle and enjoyed every minute of it, (no lookups). ‚ÄúWrigley field?‚Äù, at 27D, made me smile.  Happy weekend, everyone!
Orbed  ?  I had Orred  for a bit and was scratching my head  and  wondering if we were looking at Boolean operations.   Neither words suggests encircled, but one gave me happy music.

How fitting to finally solve this challenging gem with ATANEND :) 

And how worrisome to have CU_ for ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a mouthful.‚Äù  Umm :/

This was so great!

As is often the case on Saturday, I had almost nothing on my first across and down pass. I was tempted to start looking up names, Andrzej-style, but then I thought: the clues I did get were really cool! Why not give myself a chance of enjoying the rest of them unaided? And that's what I did - I filled the grid quite quickly in the end, without outside help ü§©

The clueing was really nice and on my wavelength, apparently. Not knowing some names and expressions did not stop me. TOP BANANA I've never heard before, I think, but I love it üòÄ. TEENTSY - that just looks so weird! I realized it had to be something like that when I got some crosses there, but I was still surprised by what emerged, exactly. 

Nice coincidence BTW - I only got TANTO because recently I've been playing the latest installment of the Assassin's Creed franchise: Shadows. It takes place in feudal Japan, and my awesome female shinobi protagonist has a TANTO in her arsenal, as well as a katana, some kunai and shuriken ü§©. It's a huge game and I've only just begun it, but it's wowing me already with its depiction of the historical era. The graphics on PS5 are amazing, too, and the gameplay is very smooth. It's nice that I experienced a connection between two great games: the PS5 one and today's wonderful grid üôÇ

Lifelong tuxie adopter so I loved that one - especially crossing him with SANDBOX :0)

Got my Cubs and Hawkeyes involved today as well

Thinking further about the puzzle...

25D [Good Samaritan, maybe]...I don't think the point of the parable is that the Good Samaritan was especially good--he was just being a decent human being.  Sure he was being better than others, but he was just doing what we *all* are supposed to be doing.  

Not just the saints.  

Whoever they are.

I wish I was a saint.

Unusually enjoyable Saturday puzzle. Not all that easy for me, of course, and had to look up some things, but just had a great time working things out from the crosses. Eight debut answers in this one and most of them pretty familiar terms - SANDBOXES, BACKSTORIES, CHEWINGGUM, EATMYDUST and others. Was really surprised to see that. 

Two thumbs up. I'll put my puzzle find for today in a reply. 

..

Sacre Coeur was built between 1875 and 1914. It is by far the newest of the city‚Äôs tourist-attraction churches. You could use lots of adjectives to describe it (‚Äòugly‚Äô springs to mind).  ‚ÄòHistoric‚Äô is not one of them

I made this harder for myself than it needed to be by sticking with some wrong answers for too long.

24A clEar for BLESS
31A AilED for ACHED
35A suet for RICE
40A Inexplicably, PEaLED for PEELED 
41A innie for NAVEL

It's been years since I've had so many wrong turns, but I enjoyed the process of unwinding them.  

Since I don't look at the news until I've read the comics and finished my NYT puzzles, maybe I was deliberately stalling to save myself from whatever fresh aitch e el el awaits me.
Fast and fun.

I believe this is the only time out of the over two thousand NYT puzzles I've solved that the last letter to fall was in the exact center of the puzzle.

And my next action after that was to check Merriam-Webster to confirm that "orb" was a verb meaning to "encircle" something. It was labeled "archaic," but it was there. Probably something I'll never encounter again in anything I read, and certainly nothing I'd ever drop into a conversation, but I'll file it away anyway.

Probably as intended NFL for 51D caused some major issues, along with Teensie.  But it had to be trial size, then the Z must be zero, and then it was done.  Still don‚Äôt like the clue for 51D though.
Love the innocence behind "Indianan," gave me a little chuckle. We prefer Hoosier.

Now that‚Äôs entertainment:
‚Ä¢	Scintillating wordplay clues coming from all directions.  
‚Ä¢	A wealth of endearing answers: CLEAR SIGN, TUXEDO CAT, NO WORRIES, PEELED (out), RIVETED, I LIED, BACKSTORIES, PHENOM, TOP BANANA, TRIAL SIZE.
‚Ä¢	A high number (16!) of long answers, bringing interest and the fun of trying to guess them with as few crosses as possible.
‚Ä¢	A low number of three-letter answers (8), which can junk up a grid.
‚Ä¢	Lovely serendipities ‚Äì RAGU crossing a backward RAGU in the SE, ROLE above ACTOR, and the PuzzPair¬© of SANDBOXES and EAT MY DUST.
‚Ä¢	Sweet TIL that that you can put rice in a birdfeeder ‚Äì I had no idea! 
‚Ä¢	Delightful knottiness in some places balanced off by thrilling whoosheroos in others.

Splendid, this prime Saturday puzzle shimmering with quality, sending me into my day with a life-is-good smile. Thank you so much for this, Christina and Jacob!

Although I have never heard of the PHENOM Caitlin Clark, I have seen THE MONA LISA who is also quite phenomenal. The first time I saw her, so long ago, one could see her up close. Now she has become a bit ANTISOCIAL and who can blame her, not a moment‚Äôs rest. NO WORRIES though, the Louvre has so many other artworks, beautiful things that are practically ignored, that one can admire in peace.

Today‚Äôs puzzle was great! üëç Thank you, Christina and Jacob.

You know that moment when the down answer fills itself in, and by mistake you look at the *across* clue to see what it was?
CUD? Really‚Ä¶ on a Coca Cola label. Huh.

Unlike a sandbox was this puzzle:
nothing nitty, and nothing gritty.
"Orbed"?

Entered IRONMINES instantly, and the NW was finished very quickly. Made good progress until I decided the author hailed from SRILANKA instead of TRINIDAD.

Didn't know TANTO, but got it from the crosses. ORBED is rather odd, and I don't think I've *ever* seen TEENTSY before. 

All in all, I must have been tuned to the right frequency today, since I finished in about 25 minutes, just like yesterday. Nice Saturday puzzle. All the long entries seemed solid to me.

Got to see the partial solar eclipse this morning, as the sun rose over the New Jersey Highlands. Expecting sunshine and almost 80F---what a marvelous day for a bee dance.

I also disagree that the Good Samaritan is a saint. The strict definition includes "heroic virtue",  whereas one point of the parable is that the Samaritan's amount of virtue is expected of us all; it ends with "Go thou and do likewise." (Though I like @kkseattle's hymn.)
The second point, already noted by several earlier commentors, is that EVERYONE is thy neighbor.

A gentle, friendly Saturday.

During lockdown, our youngest lived at home.
A gentle, lovely gem of a human.

He showed me the game GeoGuessr (I think?)
which plops you somewhere, *anywhere* 
in any country on the planet, via Google Earth.

The game is to figure out where you are.

Little nuanced clues like striped roadside posts 
or the types of animals or trees by the roadside
telling you it looks like Cambodia, but must be, say
Laos, or something like that.

If it looked like Africa but the street signs were in
English? Bam! (Usually) Ghana or Gambia.

We‚Äôd sit on the kitchen couch and 
play as we learned,
learn as we played‚Ä¶
Just hanging out.

*deep mamma sigh*

Match Day was a week ago and he matched
with his first choice of hospital.

1,000 miles away and beginning residency.

Pretty sure ‚Äúresidency‚Äù means something
about ‚Äúliving there.‚Äù

But those many days in lockdown, 
learning to distinguish Estonia from Latvia
will remain one of *the* fondest memories
of my entire life.

It‚Äôs  funny how a memory of
something so random can envelop 
and fill one‚Äôs entire heart to the brim.

Have a beautiful Saturday all!

Hug ‚Äòem if you got ‚Äòem!

To the constructors: Caitlin Clark was a big story last year, perhaps especially for NYT readers and particularly readers of the Morning newsletter. It‚Äôs always fun to read about her and I‚Äôm not much of a sports fan. 

Great puzzle and a PB for me. ALAN Moore was a complete gimme for me - it just goes to show how different people‚Äôs spheres can be. The world is wide.

Nice Saturday - a little quick for me, but nice clueing and minimal junk, as expected for a Saturday.

But...a tanto is what we'd call a knife - specifically, it was used as westerners would use a dagger.  I suspect various outlets (like the cheap sword store cited in the column) call it a sword for marketing purposes or because of the translation of "to" (fighting blade) into sword, which usually works fine for the longer blades.  It's like calling a Bowie knife or KA-BAR a sword.

Shoto, which of course I had in there for a bit üôÑ, is what we translate as short sword.

But, some websites refer to tanto as a sword, so whatcha gonna do.  Didn't cause an existential meltdown like some questionable clues seem to cause sometimes around here üòÅ
Whenever a clue is a reference to Iowa I take a screenshot of the grid to send to the fam. I‚Äôve been doing this for years.

Three times this week we‚Äôve had IRA. I think they‚Äôre just teasing me now for my earlier complaints. The usage today was finally correct, however! No ‚Äúholding‚Äù or ‚Äúinvestment‚Äù snafu this time.
Never felt like I crushed a puzzle until today.  Done in roughly half my average time.  What a smooth and rewarding solving experience.  Thank you Christina and Jacob.

What a workout! We can skip the gym today.

Thank you Christina and Jacob

A moment of silence for all the tuxedo cats (like mine) who will have their sun naps interrupted with a phone screen excitedly shoved in their faces. "You made it in, Gus! Look, that's YOU!"

His response? I DON'T CARE üòí

Gotta teach this man how to read smh
as far my flipper, i thought it would be flipping patties; i kept trying to fit grill, cause it fit the i in the crossing

I know a certain Christina and Jacob who are going on the Naughty List....  Holy cow!

First, a TUXEDO CAT is cute, but not that fancy...CALICO, now--THAT is a fancy fur coat!  (Ask me about SweetFeet sometime...)

Next:  ORBED:  Not a fan....and furthermore:
We need to know Naipaul's birthplace, for Pete's sake????

And who allowed the spelling at 38D?  What low-down, possum-eating scurrilous villain would commit such an atrocity?
"Set your Phasers to STUN, gentlemen.  These criminals deserve to be sent to the IRON MINES!"  (Where there are no doubt ADITs, SamE.)

Funner answer for 41A:  INNIE.
An OUTIE wouldn't accumulate much lint.

Woke up to six inches of snow, so getting a Saturday solve lifted my spirits. Love winter, but we were already down to bare ground, so this will only serve as a setback for our muddy roads.

Re: Caitlyn Clark, I grew up 70s/80s playing sports through college but being an avid fan of baseball, football, etc. since it was all I was taught to value. Today I only watch women‚Äôs sports, so I am thankful for Caitlyn, Juju, Paige and all other women who paved the way, making it possible to watch more women‚Äôs sports on TV. My daughters and nieces all have our NCAA women‚Äôs March Madness brackets filled out and are watching every game. Can‚Äôt wait for WNBA season to start!

Assumption:  When solving the NY Times crossword, everyone from time to time will encounter a word they've never heard of. 
Given that, does it matter whether it exists or not?  Why?  Either way you've never heard of it and will have to make a judgement using your experience and judgement (and the crosses) to decide what the answer is supposed to be.  Despite not having heard of TEENTSY, I bet that was not the one thing that prevented anyone from completing the puzzle.  If you finished the puzzle, why care if the word exists or not?  It's a puzzle and you figured out.

Whether TEENTSY exists are not, I think it was fair, and there was no reason to infer that constructors somehow messed up.

Lovely crossword today. 
Lots of searching about and guessing as I knew none of the proper names, nor PHENOM. 
I generally don‚Äôt bother about timings but this level of crossword takes me about an hour. 

The Raiders clue seemed to cause comment - could I ask why? I did look it up. 
Magic org?

I was freaking out because I couldn't find any gimme that would start me on the puzzle. The I saw BERT Convy. I had such a crush on him. You younger folks probably have no idea who he was. Also a frequent guest  the Tonight Show with Johnny Carson. Once I got that, the rest flowed, well, if not smoothly, at least slightly humming along.

I took Saint to mean someone who helps you, as in "You are a saint. Thank you so much." So I was okay with that, once I actually sussed it out.

But this puzzle was very tough for me. My unaided time was 1h 9m.

Some many entries cost me a lot of thinking and experimenting (I guess that is obvious from my time), but once one or two fell in a sector, others tumbled on in. 

That made me realize that for those who get the various phrases quickly, the puzzle would be a quick one. Reading the comments, I see that that is true for many here.

But I  had a good work out and got my monies worth, so life is good. 

PS The entry for "encircled" was my very least favorite and the last to be entered, but with the other entries around it, it became obvious. So I guess that one was on me (along with all the others).

My only quibble (and I really enjoyed that puzzle) was tanto as an answer for Japanese short sword - it‚Äôs really more of a dagger. The wakizashi is actually the short sword worn in tandem with the katana. Otherwise, lots of fun!
This was a good one. Since Magic org was NBA I just knew Raiders org would be NFL. Oh, well. Good change - took me a while to figure it out. Teentsy was also a tough one for me.

TEENTSY? 

Google says no. Internet says no. 

Apart from that, it was hard but fair and fun.
Had Shenom for phenom for a long time believing it was such a clever name for a female phenom :)

34A has me wondering about heavenly bodies:
Has the Moon got the most man-made things encircling it,
or is Mars orbeder?

It's true. If you're out of birdseed, rice and beans make a tasty meal.

Wiggly Field Dog Park is okay but it's almost all asphalt and gravel. Grass would be easier on the paws. And the L roars by all too frequently. (Yes, Barry, the L I say)

Nobody knows if Wiggly Field or Wrigley Field came first, but it's something to chew on. 

I have one teentsty nit--it should be ZERO SUGARs.
45A hint should probably say "blond" instead of "blonde."

Tiny,
Teeny,
Teensy,
TEENTSY.

As the item gets smaller, the word gets bigger.
Sent 1A to my friend in a heavy metal band. I hope they‚Äôre not disappointed at the new venue. :p

Never heard of TEENTSY, but the crosses took "teensie" away. 
Ok, everyone together now..."Two, three, four tell the people what she wore! It was an...." 
Earworm for the day - you're welcome!

I sure do miss my tuxedo cat! Answering that clue brought back happy memories.

Fun puzzle!
teentsy?  cmon.
I kept thinking I knew 16A, but I wasn't expecting a sor I wasn't expecting a sort of literal translation, Áü≠ÂàÄ, that I don't remember ever seeing or hearing before!
We had a hard time getting around "orbed" and were a teensy bit annoyed by the extra "T", but otherwise an excellent puzzle.

Ah, lovely to be greeted by a TUXEDO CAT as I return to the puzzles after a week away.
A sea of white space stymied me for a TEENTSY bit at first, but then it all filled in. I did worry about what the competitor was telling us to EAT.

No post on the Strands puzzle? Did they delete that again?
I wasn‚Äôt moving off of EtTubrUte for ‚ÄúCry from a cutthroat competitor‚Äù easily. I realize it falls apart under any examination, but I wanted it.

No time to read the comments today, but wanted to say how much I enjoyed this puzzle. Finished in my usual time but it seemed as though almost every answer wasn't the first meaning I thought of, or the second, but at least the third. And every one of them immensely fair. 

Happy to learn a couple of new things through the crosses, but mostly it was just waking up my brain by digging down through layers of word meanings. (I'm looking at you, "Encircled.")

Now on to a totally different kind of word play for my day job.

ORBED, ok -- I learned a new form of a word today.

TEENTSY? Nah.

I had SANDBOXES filled in when I got around to the NW corner, so TIL that BIGKAHUNA and TOPBANANA have the same number of letters.
I‚Äôm out of practiced so I struggled a bit today, but things opened up when I realized that in addition to being TUBED, steak could also be CUBED.

The NE required a couple hints, but otherwise not too difficult. In any case, quite enjoyable.

I had no issue with TEENTSY, as it's a partial descriptor of an itsy-bitsy, TEENTSY-weentsy yellow polka-dot bikini!

I struggled with today's puzzle, and had to resort to Google for a few clues. 

I expect to struggled on a Saturday, but was ABASHed to see most people found it on the easier side.

Oh well, I might be having an off day.... I also found today's Strands to be quite tough. 

I had TEENsie, TEENsey, and finally TEENTSY.... none looked right but the last one fit the crosses.
My last letter was the B in ORBED. The connection between the clue and the answer seemed tenuous to me, but it got me the happy music so I wasn't going to argue, lol.

For me being alive is good enough in itself. I get to love, to cry, to be bored, to do fascinating things, to help people, to hold grudges, to travel, to nap on my sofa, to eat and drink, to struggle with that strange feeling when you need to pee but just can't be bothered to get up so you just sit there thinking about it and it's becoming more of a problem but you keep sitting...

It's been quite the journey so far, and I just don't care where it's going (the grave, ultimately, anyway). Strangely, this gives me comfort when I visit my mother's grave. She had such a great life, full of so many experiences. Who cares if it had any meaning beyond the thrill of having lived?
